prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator setup is selected to optimize the telescope time. With this setup we are able indeed to observe the J=2-1 transition of 3 CO isotopologues simultaneously: 12CO, 13CO and C18O. All 3 lines are needed to fulfil our science case. At the same time we will observe the J=3-2 DCO+ transition which is needed to trace the cold gas reservoir in the outer disk. A continuum band is also requested to study the properties of the dust. To reduce the data rate we request to bin the data using spectral averaging. This will give us a spectral resolution of ~0.16 km/s. To boost the S/N, we will rebin the data to a spectral resolution of ~0.25 km/s which is approximately 1/3 of the expected line width (~0.8 km/s).

The angular resolution of 0.3 arcsec corresponds to a linear scale of 15-20 AU radius at the distance of the targets. This is required to be able to resolve the emission and to measure the gas surface density distribution. Our targets have disk sizes of ~ 400-500 AU radius. Since our goal is to measure the disk size exactly, the largest angular scale requested is 5'', corresponding to 500 AU at 100 pc.

The sensitivity estimate is driven by the faint C18O emission in our sources. ALMA early science observations of the C18O J=2-1 line are available for a number of similar targets (HAeBe systems, e.g., HD 163296, HD 142527). We used these observations and our model predictions to estimate the sensitivity needed to detect the line with a S/N > 5 in each spectral resolution element. In the case of HD 163296, the peak line flux density is 0.7 Jy/beam at a resolution of 0.2 km/s in a beam of 0.5" x 0.4". Assuming a uniform flux distribution, the peak line flux density is ~ 0.25 Jy/beam in a beam of 0.3" x 0.3" and at similar spectral resolution. Thus to be able to detect the line emission with a S/N > 5 we need an rms ~ 0.05 Jy/beam. With a similar argument we find that for the disk around HD 142527, we would need an rms ~ 0.01 Jy/beam. The difference between the two disks is due to the different total gas mass (~ 10^-2 Msun the first, ~10^-3 Msun the second). Our goal is to measure disk masses down to a few 10^-4 Msun (Fig.3 of Science Case). According to our model predictions this corresponds to a peak line flux density (in the 0.3'' beam) of ~ 0.02-0.03 Jy/beam. Thus, to detect the line with S/N > 5 we need a sensitivity of ~ 5mJy/beam. The bandwidth used for the sensitivity estimate is 0.25 km/s. Given the expected line width in the beam of ~0.8 km/s we will have 3.2 spectral resolution elements per line per beam.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a comprehensive program to determine the basic gas properties of protoplanetary disks around young A-type stars. The primary goal is to measure the gas surface density and the total gas mass. This information is fundamental to understand the initial conditions of gas giant planet formation and make the link with directly imaged exoplanets around A-type stars. Despite their importance, the gas surface density and the total gas reservoir available to form planets in disks are poorly known. Thanks to ALMA we can now use the weak, optically thin, C18O emission to address the gas reservoir and its radial distribution. We selected a sample of nearby, isolated disks for which we have collected a large multi-wavelength data set that will complement the ALMA images. This program will have a legacy value for the whole community providing a unique benchmark for detailed disk modelling.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek, University of Amsterdam
SRON Utrecht, SRON Netherlands Institute for Space Research
